bonuses.topic: three questions on a language family

questions.question: A subgroup of the Benue-Congo branch of the Niger-Congo family, which language family consists of about 600 languages spoken across west, central and southern Africa? The name for this group translates to "people" in several of its languages.

Proto-Bantu, the proposed common ancestor language of the Bantu group, is thought to have originated in forested areas along the Sanaga River, whose source is in the Adamawa Plateau, in which present-day country?
The Bantu language known variably as Chewa, Chichewa and Nyanja is spoken in which landlocked, East African country? It shares borders with Zambia, Tanzania and Mozambique.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the contemporary American dancer and choreographer Pam Tanowitz

questions.question: Which 2018 work by Tanowitz was hailed by the New York Times as "possibly the greatest creation of dance theatre so far this century"? It was inspired by and named after a series of poems by TS Eliot that includes Burnt Norton.
Tanowitz's work includes Untitled (Souvenir), a piece created for a company founded in 1926 by which leading US dancer?
Which keyboard composition by JS Bach inspired a 2017 collaboration between Tanowitz and pianist Simone Dinnerstein? It's a set of variations said to be named after its first performer.

bonuses.topic: three questions on wine growing in northern Italy.In each case, I need the name of a region

questions.question: Which region of northeast Italy is noted for wines including Prosecco and Soave? The latter is named after a village near Verona, a major city of this region.
Wines from which northern Italian region include Barolo and the sparkling Moscato d'Asti?
Franciacorta and Lambrusco are sparkling wines from which region, Italy's most populous?

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: Right, your bonuses, then, SOAS. Latvia, whose flag you identified for your picture starter, elected its second female prime minister, Evika Silina, in September 2023. Your picture bonuses are three more flags, this time each from a country that saw their first female head of state or head of government in 2023. Name the country in each case. Firstly, this country, which elected its first female president in September 2023.
Secondly, this country, which appointed its first female prime minister, Manuela Roka Botey, in January 2023.
And finally, this country, which swore in its first female governor general in February 2023.

bonuses.topic: on German vocabulary, specifically pairs of words that differ only in the substitution of the letters I-E for the letters E-I. For example, wein, meaning wine, and Wien, the German name of the capital of Austria. In each case, give both words from the definition

questions.question: First, two six-letter words. One means unfortunately or I'm afraid so, the other means songs.
Secondly, two short words, one is a second-person possessive adjective meaning your, the other is a word meaning serve. For example, in the motto of the Prince of Wales.
And finally, two six-letter words, one means to travel or to journey, the other is a combining form meaning big or huge, for example in the name of the Ferris wheel in Vienna.

bonuses.topic: Astronomy

questions.question: Three bonus questions on the solar system. Which planet of the solar system is similar in size to Earth's outer core, having a radius of roughly 3,400km?
If superimposed on Earth, with coinciding centres, which planet's surface would fall within Earth's upper mantle?
Earth's solid inner core, with a radius of 1,220km, is roughly the same size as which dwarf planet whose mean distance from the sun is approximately six billion kilometres?

bonuses.topic: Sociology

questions.question: Three questions for you on the US sociologist Robert K Merton. Merton helped to develop what commonly used social science research method? It involves organised discussions with a selected set of people to collect opinions about a particular topic, product or service.

What term did Merton popularise to refer to the idea that a belief or expectation about a person or entity is bound to be proved correct or to come true because of conditions created by its being expressed?

Merton popularised what other two-word term, based on his hypothesis that individuals compare themselves to those who occupy a social position to which they aspire? The term describes someone whom others may seek to emulate.

bonuses.topic: on bad years in history

questions.question: According to historian Michael McCormick, the worst year to be alive was 536. This was on account of darkness, lower temperatures and crop failures across Asia, Europe and the Middle East, believed to be caused by what phenomena?
In 1672, both England and France declared war on the Dutch Republic, leading to that year becoming known by what Dutch word meaning disaster year?
Which year did Queen Elizabeth II described as an annus horribilis? Events in this year included the publication of Andrew Morton's book Diana: Her True Story, and the Windsor Castle fire.

bonuses.topic: Classical Music

questions.question: For your music bonuses, you're going to hear three pieces which took direct inspiration from it. Name the composer of each. First, for five points...
questions.answer: Richard Wagner (It is the overture to The Flying Dutchman.)

questions.question: Secondly, the 20th-century British composer of this work, which directly quotes the opening of Beethoven's final movement.
questions.answer: Michael Tippett (It is his third symphony.)

questions.question: And finally, the composer of this symphony, often referred to jokingly as Beethoven's 10th.
questions.answer: Johannes Brahms (It is his first symphony.)

bonuses.topic: Film

questions.question: Your bouncers are on screen versions of Tolstoy's Anna Karenina. MGM's 1935 adaptation of Anna Karenina was the second time which European actress played Anna? She had earlier starred in Love, a silent movie that fashioned a happy ending for the story.
Who played Anna in the 1948 film version? She received Academy Awards for her roles in Gone With The Wind and A Streetcar Named Desire.
Finally, a 2012 adaptation with a screenplay by Tom Stoppard starred which British actress in the title role?

bonuses.topic: on scientific terms named after creatures in Greek mythology. In each case, give the term from the definition

questions.question: First, the immature form of hemimetabolous insects, such as grasshoppers, cicadas or cockroaches?
A class of objects in the solar system with similarities to both asteroids and comets, they are primarily located between the orbits of Jupiter and Neptune.
An individual organism composed of cells of more than one genotype, usually resulting from the fusion of zygotes.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the theatre director Marianne Elliott

questions.question: Together with Tom Morris, Elliott won a Tony Award for best director in 2011 for a stage adaptation of which 1982 novel by Michael Morpurgo?

Elliott won a subsequent Tony Award in 2015 for the direction of which play? It was based on a book narrated by a teenager named Christopher and its title is a quotation from the Sherlock Holmes story Silver Blaze.
questions.answer: Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time

questions.question: Elliott won a Tony Award for best director of a musical in 2022 for a revival of which work by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth?

bonuses.topic: on the shipping forecast, which marked the hundredth anniversary of its first radio transmission in January 2024

questions.question: In 1861, which naval officer developed a telegraphic messaging system to warn of bad weather? He had earlier captained HMS Beagle.
The shipping forecast sea area named after Robert Fitzroy lies to the west of which other area, named after a large bay?
On the east coast of Great Britain, between Cromarty and Thames, three contiguous shipping forecast areas bear the names of rivers or estuaries. Name two of these.

bonuses.topic: three questions, SOAS, on Buddhism

questions.question: What connective term refers to the fundamental doctrines of Buddhism known in Pali as dukkha, samudaya, nirodha and marga?
Dukkha, the first noble truth, that describes the essential nature of the cycle of life, death and rebirth, is most commonly translated as what?
The fourth of the Noble Truths prescribes the way out of suffering, through practices including right view and right meditation. By what term are these practices collectively known?

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: Your picture starter was Rene Magritte's Not To Be Reproduced, which is a portrait of the poet Edward James. James was a significant patron and collector of surrealist art. And your picture bonuses are three works from his collections, name the artist in each case. First, this German artist.
Secondly, this artist, born in Argentina.
And finally, the artist who co-designed this piece with James.

bonuses.topic: related questions of uncertain identity

questions.question: What name follows that the words "who is" in titles of songs by Franz Schubert and Gerard Finzi? It is that of a character from Shakespeare's The Two Gentlemen Of Verona, the daughter of the Duke of Milan.
In the 1957 novel Atlas Shrugged, by Ayn Rand, a question that appears at the start and repeatedly throughout the novel is "who is", followed by what name?
This is a quote, "Who is this, whose name sounds just like mine and is taking advantage my notoriety?" These words are attributed to a 19th-century artist, in reference to another artist, his junior.

bonuses.topic: on sporting venues in Japan

questions.question: Which city, south of Nagoya, is a regular venue of the Formula 1 Japanese Grand Prix?
The J League club Shimizu S-Pulse is based in which city between Tokyo and Nagoya? This city was also the venue of the 2002 Fifa World Cup quarterfinal between England and Brazil.
Home to the J League club known as Consadole, the Dome Stadium is in which major city, host of the 1972 Winter Olympics?

bonuses.topic: three questions on winds

questions.question: Known as The Doctor because of its invigorating dryness in times of humidity, the Harmattan wind blows from desert regions to coastal ones in the northwest of which continent?
The strong, southeasterly wind known as the Cape Doctor takes its name from which promontory in the southern hemisphere, situated near a major city?
The wind known as the Fremantle Doctor takes its name from a city in which Australian state?

bonuses.topic: on ground-nesting birds in Britain. In each case, give the common name of the bird from the description

questions.question: Numenius arquata, the largest European wading bird, distinguished by its downturned beak. Often seen on estuaries during winter, they breed on heather moorland, heath and wetlands. A single-word answer is enough.
Circus cyaneus, a bird of prey similar in size to a buzzard. It is highly persecuted because of its perceived role in hunting grouse.
Finally, Vanellus vanellus, a member of the plover family. Also known as the peewit, they are black and white with a distinctive crest.

bonuses.topic: on events of 1720

questions.question: What event does the Encyclopaedia Britannica describe as a speculation mania that ruined many British investors of 1720?
The Quadruple Alliance of Britain, France, Austria and the Dutch Republic was directed at which country, ruled by Philip V? The war was ended by the Treaty of the Hague in February 1720.
Which grandson of James VII and II was born in Rome on the last day of 1720? He spent a short period in Scotland from 1745.

bonuses.topic: three questions on batteries

questions.question: Which American scientist and inventor first used the term "battery" in 1749 during experiments with electricity using a set of linked capacitors?
Which physicist built the first electrochemical battery in 1800 using a pile of alternating discs of two metals, such as copper and zinc, separated by cardboard soaked in salt water?
Invented in 1859, the rechargeable lead acid battery is still used to start most internal combustion engine cars. What acid does it use as an electrolyte?

bonuses.topic: Economics

questions.question: Three questions for you, LSE, on economics. The graphical representation of the distribution of income or wealth is known by what two-word term, after the US economist who first described it in 1905?

The statistical measure of inequality described by the relationship A/A+B is known by what two-word term, where A is the area between perfect equality and the Lorenz curve and B is the total area under the perfect equality line?
Using the Gini coefficient, what number would represent absolute perfect equality?

bonuses.topic: on works by the Polish sculptor Magdalena Abakanowicz. In each case, give the title of the work from the description

questions.question: First, a series of rough-hewn works conceived in the 1960s, its name is a biological term meaning study of the development of animals from the fertilised egg to the new adult organism.

Secondly, a group of large headless figures resembling tree trunks, its title is a literary term that originates in Aristotle's Poetics and means the purification of the emotions, especially through certain kinds of art.
Finally, on display in a park in Chicago, an installation comprising 106 headless and armless cast-iron figures. Its short single-word name denotes the marketplace or centre of a Greek town.

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, then, Leicester. You saw for your picture starter the variation of the George Cross on the national flag of Malta, which features an image of St George and the Dragon. Your picture bonuses will now be three more flags that feature dragons

questions.question: First, identify the dynasty or empire to which this flag belongs.
Secondly, this is the flag of what capital city?
Finally, this is the flag of which English county?

bonuses.topic: three questions on fictional artists

questions.question: First published in 1988, which novel by Margaret Atwood is narrated by painter Elaine Risley and centres on her memories of being bullied as a teenager?

The Unknown Masterpiece is an 1831 story by which French writer? It concerns fictional Old Master Frenhofer's obsessive struggles to create the ideal portrait. Paul Cezanne reportedly kept a copy by his bedside and said all painters should reread it at least once a year.
The painter Lily Briscoe, a guest of the Ramsay family, is one of the central characters in which novel by Virginia Woolf?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Second War of Scottish Independence

questions.question: With the backing of the English king, which son of a former king of Scotland invaded that country in 1332 and was crowned at Perth, usurping a throne occupied by a minor?

Which son of Robert the Bruce did Edward Balliol drive from the throne? His supporters re-established his royal authority, but in 1346, he was captured at Neville's Cross in County Durham during a raid into England.
Which town gives its name to the treaty that saw David's release and his return to Scotland? It changed hands repeatedly in the late Middle Ages, and was finally ceded to England permanently in 1482.

bonuses.topic: Biology

questions.question: Three questions for you, LSE, on insects. Derived from words meaning membrane and wing, what name is given to the large order of insects that includes ants and wasps?
Members of families such as Argidae in the order Hymenoptera are known by what common name after the large ovipositor used for cutting through plant tissues?
The robin's pincushion and oak apple are examples of protuberances induced in plants by the larvae of parasitic wasps of the family Cynipidae, known by what common name?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the film and television work of the playwright Alice Birch

questions.question: Which 1988 film by David Cronenberg did Birch develop into a television mini-series that premiered in April 2023? Rachel Weisz plays the identical twin gynaecologists played in Cronenberg's film by Jeremy Irons.

Birch co-wrote the screenplay for which 2022 film by Sebastian Lelio, based on a novel by Emma Donoghue? It stars Florence Pugh as an English nurse sent to a rural Irish village to observe a child who appears to be miraculously surviving without food.
Birch has collaborated with which Irish author, co-writing television adaptations of her novels, Conversations With Friends and Normal People?

bonuses.topic: Sports

questions.question: Your bonus questions, then, LSE, are on a sporting World Cup. In 2023, England lost 61-45 to Australia in the finals of the World Cup in which seven-a-side sport?

Since its inception in 1963, only three teams have won the Netball World Cup - Australia, New Zealand and which Caribbean island nation? They shared the title on home soil in 1979, when there was a three-way tie in the round robin tournament.
Only three countries other than Australia and New Zealand have been runners-up. England twice, Trinidad and Tobago once, and which country in 1995? They hosted the 2023 tournament.

bonuses.topic: Pop Music

questions.question: For your music starter, you heard Sunshine of Your Love by Cream, with Eric Clapton on lead guitar. Like many other notable guitarists of the 1960s, Clapton's style was heavily influenced by Chicago and Delta blues music. And for your music bonuses, you need to identify three such bluesmen. Five points for each you can name. First...
Secondly...
questions.answer: Robert Johnson with Crossroad Blues in 1937

questions.question: And finally...

bonuses.topic: on shorter words that can be made using any of the ten letters of the name Love Island. For example, dallies and evasion. In each case, give the word or name from the description

questions.question: First, an early work by Shakespeare that concerns a goddess and the object of her love, Venus and who?
Secondly, in computing, the second word represented in the acronym DDoS. This is a hostile action that attempts to flood a network connection or other service.
Finally, the collective single-word name of the film-making duo who made the award winning 2022 film Everything Everywhere All at Once.

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: But your bonuses, LSE, are on South America. In each case, identify the country from the list of its geographical features. First, Ojos del Salado, the highest terrestrial volcano in the world, and the steep rocky headland known as Cape Horn?
Secondly, the Salar de Uyuni, or Uyuni salt flat, and the south eastern part of Lake Titicaca.
Finally, the larger part of the Orinoco Basin and the petroleum rich area around Lake Maracaibo.

bonuses.topic: on flags in Formula 1

questions.question: What colour flag warns cars about to be lapped that the leading cars are approaching?
What design is the flag that warns a driver that a car has mechanical problems that could be dangerous to themselves and others?
And finally, what colour is the flag warning that drivers need to reduce their speed, cannot overtake and must be prepared to change direction due to a hazard beside or partly on the track?

bonuses.topic: on presidents of the Royal Society. In each case, identify the scientist from the description

questions.question: First, the president from 1890 to 1895. Born in Belfast, this scientist played a major role in developing the second law of thermodynamics, the dynamical theory of heat and the electromagnetic theory of light.

Secondly, the president from 1995 to 2000. This Lithuanian-born British chemist won the 1982 Nobel Prize for investigating the three-dimensional structure of viruses and for the development of crystallographic electron microscopy.
Finally, the president from 1895 to 1900, this surgeon devised antiseptic medicine and is considered a pioneer in preventive medicine.

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: Following on from that painting by Van Gogh of falling leaves in the Roman necropolis Les Alyscamps, your picture bonuses are three more paintings of autumn leaves. Again, I just want the name of the artist in each case. First, this American artist.
Secondly, this English artist.
And finally...

bonuses.topic: Fiction

questions.question: Three questions for you, LSE, on mid-Victorian fiction. The 1861 novel East Lynne by Mrs Henry Wood is an early example of what popular genre, sometimes known as novels with a secret? I need a single word that appears alongside "novel" or "fiction".
Born in 1835, which author's sensation novels include Aurora Floyd and Lady Audley's Secret?
Finally, whose sensation novels include No Name, Armadale and The Woman in White?

bonuses.topic: three questions on bird lovers

questions.question: Which US author wrote the essay Why Birds Matter And Are Worth Protecting? His 2010 novel Freedom tells the story of Walter Berglund, a man obsessed with saving birds...
Acknowledged for his ability to transform birdsong into notated music, which French composer wrote a 1958 work of 13 piano movements, each depicting a different bird?
Which former Conservative Chancellor of the Exchequer also counts birdwatching as one of his interests? He was father of the House of Commons from 2017 to 2019.

bonuses.topic: on German cities. In each case, give the four-letter name of the city described

questions.question: First, a major city on the river Rhine in North Rhine-Westphalia. It is home to the Friedrich Wilhelm University and was the birthplace of Beethoven.
Secondly, a city on the river Saale in Thuringia, home to the Friedrich Schiller University and the 19th century Carl Zeiss glass factory.
Finally, a port in Schleswig-Holstein, it is the location of the Christian Albrechts University and a major annual sailing regatta.

bonuses.topic: on poetic terms. Give each from the definition. All three are Greek-derived and all three begin with the same three letters

questions.question: First, the repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses, sentences or lines.
Secondly, a deliberate reversal of the usual syntactical order of words, such as the inversion of noun and adjective or the subject and object. This term comes from the Greek for turning back.
Finally, a metrical foot consisting of two unstressed syllables followed by a final stressed syllable. It is used notably in Byron's The Destruction of Sennacherib and many works by Dr Seuss.

bonuses.topic: Film

questions.question: Your three bonuses are on films with soundtracks composed by Jonny Greenwood. In each case, name the film from the description. First, Kristen Stewart received a Best Actress Oscar nomination for her role in this 2022 film. It is a biopic of Princess Diana directed by Pablo Larrain.
Secondly, directed by Lynne Ramsay and based on a novella by Jonathan Ames, a 2017 film in which Joaquin Phoenix plays a traumatised mercenary hired to rescue young girls who have been trafficked.
And finally, a 2007 film by Paul Thomas Anderson in which Daniel Day-Lewis won his second Oscar for his role as the oil prospector Daniel Plainview. It is based on a novel by Upton Sinclair.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the 1924 UK general election

questions.question: The 1924 UK general election was held after which Prime Minister, heading a minority government, suffered an adverse vote in the House of Commons?

Head of the Communist International, which Soviet politician was the alleged author of a seditious letter widely held to have contributed to Labour's defeat in the 1924 election? It was later shown to have been a forgery attributed to MI5 or MI6.
Which former Prime Minister lost his seat to Labour at Paisley in the 1924 election? Lloyd George later replaced him as the Liberal Party leader.

bonuses.topic: three questions on magnetism

questions.question: What term is used to quantify the magnetic field passing through a surface? Commonly represented by the Greek letter phi, its SI unit is the weber.

Which two French physicists give their names to an equation that describes the magnetic field produced by a steady current distribution, taking into account the differential contributions of each infinitesimal current element along the path?
Which scientist gives his name to the principle of electromagnetism that describes how a change in magnetic flux through a closed circuit induces an electromotive force of voltage in that circuit?

bonuses.topic: on members of the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen - in the comic book series of the same name by Alan Moore and Kevin O'Neill. All are reimaginings of characters from well-known 19th-century novels

questions.question: In Volume One, who assembles and leads the League at the behest of Campion Bond? This character was introduced in a Gothic novel of 1897 and appears in Moore's comics under her maiden name, having divorced her husband, Jonathan.

Next, the character of Dr Hawley Griffin is based on the protagonist of which 1897 novel by HG Wells? In Wells' novel, this character conducts experiments on his own body which prove to be irreversible and drive him to madness and a life of crime.
League member Prince Dakkar is also known by what alias? This character is the only one of Mina's recruits who originates in a non-English-language work.

bonuses.topic: on pairs of people whose surnames differ only in that their initial letters are consecutive letters of the alphabet, for instance, Brown and Crown. In each case, give both surnames from the description

questions.question: First, a US aviator, one of the pair who, in 1932, along with Thomas Cox Allen, became the first black man to fly across the United States, and the former Foreign Secretary who served 119 days as UK Prime Minister in 1827.
A Welsh post-Impressionist known for female portraits, such as Girl With A Cat, and the scientist who received the 1998 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing the density functional theory.
An Israeli-British illusionist known for his spoon-bending performances and a US author whose best-known novel includes the characters Colonel Cathcart and Milo Minderbinder.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the artist Douglas Gordon

questions.question: A major 1993 work by Gordon consists of a projection of which film of 1960 slowed to a rate of approximately two frames per second so that it lasts for precisely 24 hours?

In a 1997 installation by Gordon, William Friedkin's The Exorcist and Henry King's The Song Of Bernadette are projected simultaneously on opposite sides of a translucent screen. Its title is Between Darkness And Light, followed by the name of which poet and painter born in 1757?

Which football player is the subject of a feature-length documentary of 2006 by Gordon and Philippe Parreno? Using 17 cameras, the film follows this midfielder throughout an entire Real Madrid versus Villarreal match.

bonuses.topic: Pop Music

questions.question: For your music starter, you heard Tattoo by Loreen, which won the 2023 Eurovision Song Contest. That win led to Sweden hosting the 2024 contest on the 50th anniversary of Abba's win with Waterloo. For your music bonuses, you'll hear three Eurovision entries that won on a milestone anniversary of a previous win. Here, I want you to name both the artist and the country they represented. First, for five points.
Secondly.
And finally...
questions.answer: Katrina and the Waves and the UK

bonuses.topic: on esters, the class of compounds produced when acids and alcohols combine and release water. In each case, identify the substance or compound from the description

questions.question: First, extremely sensitive to shock and rapid heating, a key ingredient of dynamite that is used in medicine to ease cardiac pain.
Secondly, a wax secreted by Copernicia prunifera, a species of palm tree native to Brazil. It consists primarily of esters of long-chain alcohols and acids, and is used in high-gloss polishes.
And finally, a mild non-narcotic pain reliever effective in reducing fever and inflammation. It reduces the risk of heart attack or stroke in high-risk individuals if a low dose is taken daily.

bonuses.topic: on Australia. In each case, name the state or territory in which the following are located

questions.question: First, the Torres Strait Islands, the Cape York Peninsula and the Gold Coast region.
Second, the Barossa Valley, the Eyre Peninsula and the opal-producing centre of Coober Pedy.
Finally, the Great Sandy Desert, the Swan Coastal Area and the Pilbara region, a major centre of iron ore mining.

bonuses.topic: on a play

questions.question: Millennium Approaches and Perestroika are the names of the two parts of which play...?

In the epilogue of Angels In America, the characters Prior, Hannah and two others gather around which fountain in New York's Central Park? It shares its name with the site of a healing miracle performed in the Bible and a town in north-west Wales.
In the play, the ghost of which person tells Roy Cohn, "Julius sends his regards"? In real life, Cohn was a prosecutor in the 1951 trial of this person.

bonuses.topic: Film

questions.question: For your picture bonuses, you need to identify three more recent examples of courtroom films. Five points for each you can name. First, this 2022 film.
Secondly, from 2023.
Finally, this 2020 film about a historical event.

bonuses.topic: three questions on a fashion designer

questions.question: The premiere of which British fashion designer's 1999 spring-summer collection, Number 13, featured model Shalom Harlow being spray painted by two robot arms while standing on a rotating platform?
For his 2001 spring-summer collection, Voss, McQueen constructed a dress using the shells of which long bivalve? Its scientific name is Ensis magnus.
Described as a biological hybridisation of women with sea mammals, McQueen's final collection to premiere before his death was named after which mythological location?

bonuses.topic: on Latin American dance forms. Name each from the description

questions.question: First, a dance from Cuba that developed from the contradanza in the 19th century and later gave rise to the cha-cha-cha. It features notably in the 1957 musical...
Second, a fast closed-position couples dance in two or four time. It is the national dance of the Dominican Republic.
Finally, an Argentine dance in slow 2-4 or 4-4 time that developed during the late 19th century. In its traditional form, it is semi-improvised.

bonuses.topic: on British birds whose scientific names are reduplicative, meaning the same word is used for both genus and species. A single-word answer is sufficient in each case

questions.question: Apus apus is the binomial of which bird that lives almost its entire life on the wing, "apus" meaning without feet?
Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax, meaning flame-coloured raven, is the scientific name for the red-billed species of which corvid associated particularly with Cornwall?
Pica pica is the binomial for the Eurasian or common species of which bird?

bonuses.topic: Link (British Geography, Drama, Painting/Sculpture)

questions.question: Three questions for you, Edinburgh, on cultural references to the word rose. Which ballet features the Rose Adagio, a notoriously demanding set piece in which the ballerina in the title role performs four unsupported balances whilst en pointe?
Who wrote the 1941 play Rose Tattoo? It's the story of Serafina, a Sicilian-American seamstress who learns of her husband's infidelity after he is killed by the police.
The Soul Of The Rose is a 1908 work by which English artist? It depicts a young woman in a garden, taking in the scent of a pink climbing rose.

bonuses.topic: three questions on canals

questions.question: Which early canal, located in Greater Manchester, takes its name from the noble title of the colliery owner Francis Egerton, born in 1736?
Named after two rivers, which canal runs from Bath to Newbury, thereby linking Bristol with London?
Named in part after an English county, which canal runs north-west from Wolverhampton, meeting the Manchester Ship Canal at the town of Ellesmere Port?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Australian Aboriginal actor David Gulpilil

questions.question: Gulpilil made his feature-film debut aged 16 in which 1971 film by Nicolas Roeg? Jenny Agutter and Roeg's son, Luc, play children who are abandoned in the Australian outback. Gulpilil's character helps them survive.

bonuses.topic: on animals named after islands or island groups to which they are endemic. In each case, give the two-word common name of the species from the description

questions.question: First, a reptilian apex predator of the genus Varanus, found only on a few small islands in Indonesia.
Secondly, an avian species which is the northernmost member of the family Spheniscidae. It inhabits a Pacific archipelago on the equator.
And finally, a large carnivorous marsupial, which, along with the quolls and marsupial mice, makes up the family Dasyuridae.

bonuses.topic: three questions, St Andrews, on a sculpture

questions.question: A version of a bust of Helen of Troy from the collection of Lord Londonderry, sold at auction in 2023 for £3.5 million. It is a work by which Italian neoclassical sculptor, born in 1757? Another version of the sculpture is in the collection of the V&A.

The bust sold at auction was originally a gift from Canova to which leading Anglo-Irish statesman in thanks for his work in repatriating art looted from Italy by Napoleon? As Foreign Secretary, he was the dominant British presence at the Congress of Vienna following the Napoleonic Wars.

This is a quote. "In this beloved marble view, above the works and thoughts of man, what nature could but would not do, and beauty and Canova can." Which Romantic poet wrote those words, having seen the sculpture while in Venice in 1816?

bonuses.topic: on alternative methods of musical notation. In each case, simply give the style of notation from a description

questions.question: First, a style of notation developed in the second half of the 20th century. It uses visual elements and diagrams to suggest what the performer might play.
Secondly, a scoring system used primarily in Baroque music. It uses numbers and accidentals to indicate the harmonies to be played above a given line.
And finally, a system of notation most commonly associated with plucked string instruments such as the guitar. It indicates finger positions on a fretboard rather than musical notes.

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: Your picture starter showed the ports of Mobile, Alabama, and Coatzacoalcos in Veracruz, which, as of 2024, are linked by a roll-on-roll-off train ferry operated by CG Railway, and capable of carrying more than 100 rail freight cars. For your picture bonuses, you're now going to see maps of three more places linked by roll-on-roll-off rail ferries. First, name the terminal city on the west here, marked with a pin.
Secondly, I want you to name the two provinces highlighted here.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the revolutionary leader Tupac Amaru II

questions.question: In the 1780s, Tupac Amaru II led a revolt against Spanish colonial rule that began in which modern-day country?

bonuses.topic: on medical terms. Give each from the definition. All three begin with the same three letters

questions.question: First, the process of filtering substances from a solution by selective diffusion through a semi-permeable membrane. This process takes place naturally in the kidneys to remove waste and toxins from the blood, and may be artificially replicated to treat kidney failure.
Secondly, a medicine used to treat anxiety, insomnia and muscle spasms or seizures, it works by increasing the effect of gamma-aminobutyric acid in the brain, and its trade names include Valium.
Finally, the phase of a heartbeat that occurs between two contractions of the heart, during which the heart muscles relax and the ventricles fill with blood.

bonuses.topic: on world events. In each case, name the venue of the Summer Olympic Games in the years that the following events occurred. Note that the events of each list are not confined to a single year

questions.question: First, William McKinley and Calvin Coolidge win US presidential elections, the former being re-elected. Remember, I want the name of the one city that hosted the games in both those years.
Secondly, the unsuccessful cull in Western Australia known as the Great Emu War, Band Aid released Do They Know It's Christmas.
Finally, the Tunguska event in Siberia. President Truman authorises the Marshall Plan. Spain wins the UEFA European Championship for the second time in succession.

questions.question: Three questions for you, UEA, on rivers of Western Europe. First, a leading wine-producing region, which autonomous community of northern Spain takes its name from a tributary of the River Ebro?

Finally, Chateauneuf du Pape is a noted wine appellation in which wine-growing region, named after a major river?

Named after the Greek demon of lawlessness, Dysnomia is the only known moon of which dwarf planet?
Finally, named after figures from Greek mythology Hydra, Kerberos, Styx, Nyx and Charon all orbit which dwarf planet?

bonuses.topic: questions on brass band instruments

questions.question: Developed in the 19th century as a valved form of the post horn, which high-pitched brass band instrument takes its name from an Old French word meaning "little horn"? It often plays the melody in a brass band.
What brass band instrument is at the same pitch as the cornet, but has a wider conical bore, giving it a fuller tone? Its name comes from the German for "wing".
One of the lower instruments, which brass band instrument is often regarded as a smaller member of the tuba family? Its name derives from the Greek for "good sound".

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Swedish writer Sven Lindqvist

questions.question: An inspiration for an HBO documentary series of the same name, Lindqvist's book on colonial racism and genocide, Exterminate All The Brutes, takes its title from words in which 1899 novel by Joseph Conrad?
Lindqvist's travelogue Terra Nullius is an exploration of white settlers on the landscape and peoples of which country? In one section of the book, Lindqvist visits the Maralinga nuclear test site.

bonuses.topic: Mythology

Which Titan and fire deity is the father of Deucalion? He is the subject of plays by Aeschylus and PB Shelley.
Finally, what was the name of the son of Deucalion and Pyrrha? Traditionally, he is said to be the eponymous ancestor of the Greek tribes.

bonuses.topic: three questions on pre-telescopic observatories in the Islamic world

questions.question: First, born in 985, the Fatimid caliph al-Hakim built an observatory at Mount Mokattam, near which present-day capital? The precise observations, known as the Hakimi Tables, were compiled there.
Significant in the development of Islamic astronomy, the Observatory of Maragheh was founded by a Mongol conqueror in 1259 south of Tabriz in which present-day country?
In 1429, Ulugh Beg, the grandson of Timur, built a noted observatory in which historic city now in Uzbekistan?

bonuses.topic: on marriage proposals in the novels of Thomas Hardy. In each case, identify the novel from the quote

questions.question: First, Angel to the title character, "I shall soon want to marry and, being a farmer, you see I shall require for my wife a woman who knows all about the management of farms. Will you be that woman?"
Second, Thomasin to Damon, "Here am I asking you to marry me when, by rights, you ought to be on your knees imploring me not to refuse you, and saying it would break your heart if I did."
Lucetta to the title character, "I soon learned that you had planned to marry me out of mere charity, almost as an unpleasant duty because I had nursed you."

Secondly, the prehensile-tailed hutia, the little goblin bat and the bee hummingbird, the smallest bird species on Earth.
Finally, the aye-aye, the fossa and the comet moth, one of the world's largest moths.

questions.question: In a cubic equation, all of whose coefficients are real and positive, how many real positive roots are there?

How many distinct real roots has the equation x cubed + 3x squared + 3x + 1 = 0?

bonuses.topic: three questions on geology
