bonuses.topic: three questions on chemistry

questions.question: For what do the letters EPR stand in the acronym VSEPR, or Vesper, referring to a common model used to predict the three-dimensional arrangement of atoms and molecules?

For main group elements, the Vesper model suggests that a molecule in which the central atom has three ligands and two lone electron pairs will resemble what uppercase letter of the Roman alphabet? An example is chlorine trifluoride.
Which scientist gives his name to a modification of Vesper theory that makes it applicable to transition metal complexes?

bonuses.topic: Mathematics

questions.question: Three questions, for you Imperial, on set theory. In set theory, the abbreviation ZF denotes an axiomatic system proposed in the early 20th century to address paradoxes in naive set theory. It stands for the names of two mathematicians. Name either.

NBG set theory is a conservative extension of the Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms that introduces the concept of class and is thereby finitely axiomatizable. Give any two of the three mathematicians denoted by the letters NBG.

The abbreviation AC denotes which historically controversial addition to the ZF axioms? This states that for any set of mutually exclusive sets, there is at least one set that contains exactly one element in common with each of the non-empty sets.

bonuses.topic: three questions on a satirical poem

questions.question: The 1681 poem Absalom and Achitophel is based on the biblical story of Absalom's rebellion against his father, King David, and was a satire on the exclusion crisis. Which poet wrote it?
In the poem, King David represents Charles II and Absalom the Duke of Monmouth. Which Whig politician is portrayed as Achitophel, the plotting counsellor?
The story of Absalom's rebellion against King David appears in a book in the Old Testament named for which figure?

bonuses.topic: on women with the given name Marianne. Give the surname of each from the description

questions.question: First, an English biologist and botanical artist born in 1830. Around 800 of her paintings and drawings are housed in a namesake gallery in Kew Gardens.

Secondly, a modernist poet born in Missouri in 1887 who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1951. Her works include poetry in which she describes the aim of poetry as the creation of imaginary gardens with real toads in them.
Finally, a British theatre director. Born in 1966, she won the Tony Award for Best Director for her productions of War Horse and The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time.

bonuses.topic: Classical Music

questions.question: Your music starter a moment ago was Capriccio by Leos Janacek, whose archives have been inscribed on UNESCO's Memory of the World Register, a list compiled to help preserve evidence of world heritage and culture. For your music bonuses, Trinity, you'll hear three more works by composers whose works or archives also appear on this list. First, who is this Soviet composer?
questions.answer: Aram Khachaturian (The piece is the Waltz from his Masquerade Suite.)

questions.question: Secondly, this Austrian composer.
questions.answer: Arnold Schoenberg (The excerpt is taken from the introduction of his Variations for Orchestra, Op. 31.)

questions.question: Finally...
questions.answer: Frédéric Chopin (The piece is his "Military" Polonaise in A major, Op. 40 No. 1)

bonuses.topic: three questions on American observatories

questions.question: First, built near Socorro in New Mexico, which Y-shaped 27-element radio interferometer is officially named for the pioneer of radio astronomy, Karl Jansky, but is more commonly known by a three-letter initialism?

In size, just exceeding the Effelsberg 100-metre dish thanks to its slightly elliptical design, the largest steerable single-dish radio telescope can be found at which radio observatory in West Virginia?
Finally, until it collapsed in December 2020, a 300m aperture fixed-dish radio telescope was found at Arecibo Observatory site on which island?

bonuses.topic: questions on the minimalist composer Pauline Oliveros

questions.question: In 1962, Oliveros co-founded the Tape Music Center in which US city? The centre was the location of the first performance of Terry Riley's In C, featuring Oliveros herself and Steve Reich.

What two-word name did Oliveros use to describe the practice of careful attention to sound that she developed and taught? She coined it initially as a punning title for a recording made in an underground cistern.

Finally, based on a hexagonal map of possible performer choices, the 1999 work Six For A New Time was written by Oliveros for which alternative rock band founded by Thurston Moore, Kim Gordon and Lee Ranaldo?

bonuses.topic: Religion

questions.question: Three questions for you, Imperial, on syncretic religions and beliefs. Cao Dai is a syncretic religion that draws on elements of Taoism, Confucianism, Roman Catholicism and Buddhism. It was formally established in 1926 in which Asian country?
Next, Santeria, also known as Regla de Ocha and Lucumi, is a religious tradition of African origin that developed in the 19th century on which Caribbean island?
Candomble is a syncretic religion of African origin that originated in which populist country?

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: For your picture starter, Trinity, you saw one of Diego Rivera's Detroit Industry Murals and, for your bonuses, you'll see three more early-20th-century paintings of factories. Name the artist in each case. First, this French artist.
questions.answer: Fernand Léger (The painting is Le Transport des Forces, or Transport of Forces.)

questions.question: Secondly, this is a sketch by which Italian-born architect, a member of the futurist movement?
questions.answer: Antonio Sant'Elia (The sketch is of a power station in 1914.)

questions.question: Finally, this American futurist.
questions.answer: Joseph Stella (The painting is By-Products Plants.)

bonuses.topic: on two-hander plays - that is, those with only two main characters

questions.question: First performed in 1961, Happy Days features the married couple Winnie and Willie, and is described as being set in a mound of sand.
Later revised in the 1970s under the title Out Cry, The Two-Character Play is among the later works of which playwright, born in Mississippi in 1911?
Which two-hander by David Mamet concerns the conflict between a university professor at a student who accuses him of harassment?

bonuses.topic: on post-growth economics, a theory of economics that looks beyond conventional measures of prosperity

questions.question: Introduced in 2006 by the New Economics Foundation, what index adds to the Human Development Index by taking sustainability into account?
Initially a report for the Sustainable Development Commission, Prosperity Without Growth was first published in 2009 by which British economist?
Finally, the British economist Kate Raworth developed what economic framework highlighting needs that must be met without overshooting ecological ceilings?

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, Imperial, three questions on the city of Palermo in Sicily

questions.question: First, now home to the Sicilian Regional Assembly, the Royal Palace of Palermo is also known by the name of which people who captured the city under the Guiscard brothers in 1072?
Later, in the early 13th century, which German emperor, the grandson and namesake of Barbarossa, established his court at Palermo?
In 1735, the future Charles III of Spain was crowned King of Sicily in Palermo Cathedral. He was a member of which Royal House?

bonuses.topic: two questions on plants

questions.question: From the Latin for "juice", what term denotes a plant with fleshy, thick tissues adapted to water storage?

Succulents employ a modified version of carbon dioxide fixation and photosynthesis known as CAM, C-A-M, in which the letter C stands for crassulacean after a family of plants. For what do the letters A-M stand?
What large genus of succulents includes the commercially important sisal and cantala, and the blue species that is used to make tequila?

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: Three questions for you, Imperial, on rivers of Russia. Yakutsk is a port on which major river? The easternmost of the major Siberian rivers, it flows from the area around Lake Baikal to the Laptev Sea.
The Trans-Siberian Railway crosses which river at Novosibirsk, the most populous city of Siberia? This river forms a major system along with its tributary, the Irtysh.
Which river rises to the south-east of Moscow and flows for more than 1,800km into the Sea of Azov?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Assyrian King Sennacherib

questions.question: Born in 745 BC, Sennacherib transferred his capital to which city close to present-day Mosul?

Defying advice from the Prophet Isaiah, which King of Judah formed an alliance to rebel against Sennacherib? In the second book of Kings, it is said that "after him was none "like him among all the kings of Judah, "nor any that were before him."
What four words complete the first line of Byron's poem The Destruction Of Sennacherib - The Assyrian came down like the...

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, Imperial, three questions on fictional bookworms

questions.question: In a 2007 work by Junot Diaz, which New Jersey teenager gorges himself on speculative fiction by authors such as Wells, Burroughs, Howard, Asimov and Heinlein?
questions.answer: Oscar Wao or Oscar de León

questions.question: In which novel do Elena and Lila read Louisa May Alcott's Little Women so often that the book begins to fall apart? It is the first in Elena Ferrante's Neapolitan series.
What three words describe Liesel Meminger in the title of a novel set during World War II by the Australian Markus Zusak?

bonuses.topic: on subjects of portraits by the Abstract Expressionist Elaine de Kooning. Name each person from the description

questions.question: First, an American dancer and choreographer born in 1919. In collaboration with his long-term partner, John Cage, he created many pieces incorporating an element of chance, beginning... [gong]

bonuses.topic: three questions on Jason and the Argonauts

questions.question: Born in about 295 BCE, which Hellenistic author wrote The Argonautica, an epic poem that recounts the voyage of Jason and the Argonauts?
Which leading hero accompanied the Argonauts on the early part of their voyage but remained behind to look for his companion Hylas who had been entrapped by water nymphs?

Finally, when the Argo approaches Crete on the return journey, the bronze giant Talos attempts to wreck the ship with rocks. According to The Argonautica, who bewitches the eyes of Talos and defeats him through sorcery?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a group of artists

questions.question: From a Hebrew word meaning prophet, what name was assumed in the 1890s by a group of French artists, including Maurice Denis and Edouard Vuillard who are heavily influenced by Paul Gauguin's use of flat area of colour and rhythmic patterns?

The first Nabi work is usually held to be The Talisman, created in 1888 under Gauguin's guidance by which artist, the Nabis' principal driving force? It depicts a bridge over water as a near-abstract assembly of bright, coloured patches.

Born in 1867, which member of the group was known as the Nabi "plus japonard" - referring to the influence of Japanese wood block prints on his work? He is known for his intimate, intensely coloured domestic scenes and his representation of textiles.

bonuses.topic: three questions on microbiology

questions.question: First, the effectiveness of an antimicrobial agent may be expressed as MIC. For what does this abbreviation stand?
Next, the viable number of bacteria in a culture is sometimes expressed by the abbreviation CFU. For what do these three letters stand?
Finally, similarly, the number of virus particles may be expressed as PFU. For what does the letter P for papa stand in this case?

bonuses.topic: Poetry

questions.question: You saw an extract from Sir Gawain And The Green Knight. Your picture bonuses are three more extracts from the opening lines of medieval works. In each case, I need the title figure of the work. First, who is the title figure of this medieval poem?
Second, the title figure of this work?
questions.answer: El Cid (from El Cantar de mio Cid)

questions.question: Finally, the title character of this work.
questions.answer: King Arthur (from Sir Thomas Malory's Le Morte d'Arthur)

bonuses.topic: questions on Eurasian nomads of late antiquity and the early Middle Ages

questions.question: Thought to be of Iranian origin, which steppe nomads were forced westward by the Huns and later formed a kingdom with the Vandals in North Africa? In the east, their kingdom in the Caucasus survived until the Mongol invasion.

In the sixth century, which people founded a khaganate in the Pannonian Plain by ousting the Germanic Gepids? They later expanded into the Balkan territories of the Byzantine Empire but submitted to Charlemagne in 805.
Khan Asparuh led which Turkic nomadic people to found an empire in the Balkans where they eventually adopted a Slavic language and cultural practices?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a poet and her works

questions.question: I, Being Born A Woman And Distressed, and Time Does Not Bring Relief are sonnets by which US poet born in 1892?
Give the single-word title of the long lyric poem by Millay that begins, "All I could see from where I stood "was three long mountains and a wood."
Which Ancient Greek mathematician is the subject of a sonnet by Millay that states, "He alone has looked on beauty bare"?

bonuses.topic: three questions on metallic elements and their ores

questions.question: Dolomite is an industrially significant ore of calcium and which other group 2 metal which may be obtained from it via the Pidgeon Process?

Which transition metal is principally obtained today from the mineral pentlandite? Much of the world's supply is mined from a large deposit in Sudbury, Canada, believed to be the result of an ancient meteorite impact.
Which metal's major ores include sphalerite, smithsonite, and hemimorphite - the latter two formerly grouped together under the name calamine?

bonuses.topic: Classical Music

questions.question: A moment ago you heard Symphony No 100 by Joseph Haydn, who is often described as the Father of the Symphony. Your music bonuses, Trinity, are three more pieces by composers who are similarly influential in the development of a particular form. In each case, simply identify the composer. First, the composer of this piece, born in the Duchy of Milan.
questions.answer: Claudio Monteverdi (He is a key figure in the development of opera; the aria is In questo lieto e fortunato giorno from L'Orfeo.)

questions.question: This composer, born in the Papal States.
questions.answer: Arcangelo Corelli (He is a key figure in the development of concerto grosso; the excerpt is taken from the last movement of his Concerto Grosso in D major, Op. 6 No. 4.)

questions.question: Finally, this composer, born in Naples.
questions.answer: Domenico Scarlatti (He wrote 555 keyboard sonatas; the piece is his Sonata in E Major, K.20.)

bonuses.topic: Classical Music

questions.question: Three bonuses, Birkbeck, on classical music and literature. First, the last major works of Jean Sibelius include incidental music for which late play by Shakespeare? Notable sections include The Chorus Of The Winds, The Oak Tree and The Rainbow.

Which British composer adapted The Tempest into an opera first performed in 2004 with a libretto by Meredith Oakes? His other works include the chamber opera Powder Her Face and the piano concerto In Seven Days.
Finally, born in 1840, which Russian composer wrote an 1873 symphonic poem based on The Tempest, in addition to overture-fantasias, based on Romeo And Juliet and Hamlet?

bonuses.topic: on common food stabilisers

questions.question: First, in the 1950s, a team led by US chemist Allene Jeanes developed a process for manufacturing which polysaccharide, by fermenting sugar with its namesake bacterium? A widely used emulsifier and thickening agent, it is often used as a binder in gluten-free baking and as an egg substitute.

Next, which hydrophilic gum is obtained principally from the red alga Chondrus crispus, otherwise known as the Irish moss? It is particularly useful in stabilising dairy products as it reacts strongly with milk proteins.

Finally, which gelling agent, used widely in the commercial production of jams and marmalades, occurs in the cell walls and intercellular tissues of most fruits, where it acts as a kind of cement? The peels of citrus fruits are particularly rich sources.

bonuses.topic: three questions on vector calculus

questions.question: If phi is a scalar function of the variables X, Y and Z, which vector quantity in terms of phi gives the normal to the surface of constant phi?
What name is given to the scalar property representing the flux generation per unit volume at each point of a vector field F? When this quantity is zero, F is said to be solenoidal.
What four-letter term denotes the circulation per unit area of a vector field, representing the vorticity of the field? Where this expression is zero, the field is said to be irrotational.

bonuses.topic: Link

questions.question: You just saw the memorial to Edith Cavell, who is the subject of a biography by the English author Diana Souhami. For your picture bonuses, then, Birkbeck, three more people who are the subjects of lives by Souhami. Five points for each you can name. First, this English author.
Next, the artist who painted this portrait and appears on the right.
Finally, this Hollywood figure.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the film director Youssef Chahine

questions.question: Played by the director himself, a homeless disabled young man named Qinawi is the protagonist of which 1958 neorealist film by Chahine? Its two-word English title refers to the transport terminus in Egypt where Qinawi begins working.
Referring to his place of birth, what is the title of Chahine's 1979 autobiographical film, awarded the Silver Bear at that year's Berlin Film Festival?
In The Blazing Sun, Chahine gave which Egyptian actor his first film role? His first English language role came eight years later in a film directed by David Lean.

bonuses.topic: on cities that have hosted the biennial F-I-S-U, FISU World University Games. Name each city from the description

questions.question: First, the 2003 host. A large city in South Korea, about 90km north-west of Busan, it is known for its textile industry and as the centre of a notable apple-growing region.
Secondly, host of the 2005 games. A seaport in Turkey with a population of three million, it is one of the largest cities of the Aegean Sea and one of the oldest of the Mediterranean world.
One of the most popular cities on the Volga, it lies around 60km north of its confluence with the Kama and is the capital of the Republic of Tatarstan.

bonuses.topic: questions on Irish political leaders

questions.question: First, a key founder of the Society of United Irishmen, which Dublin barrister sought aid from Revolutionary France in support for an Irish insurrection? He was captured in 1798 and died by his own hand before he could be executed.
Next, born in County Kerry in 1775, who is known as the Liberator for his part in forcing the British to grant Catholic emancipation? He gives his name to a wide avenue in Dublin.
Finally, which leader of the Home Rule Movement and the National Land League saw his career collapse in 1890 when he was cited in the O'Shea divorce case?

bonuses.topic: on digraphia, that is, instances in which a language is written with more than one script

questions.question: First, which language is written in two scripts, Shahmukhi and Gurmukhi deriving from Perso-Arabic scripts and Brahmic scripts respectively? The divide in usage falls largely along national and confessional lines.
In 2020, the government of which country announced plans to promote the traditional vertical script of its national language to official status...?
Which language was first written with Chinese characters known as Hanja, which persisted alongside the novel Hangul script from 1446?

bonuses.topic: on medicine. In each case, give the term from the definition. All three answers are words of hybrid Greek-Latin derivation, for example, neo-natal or hyperactive

questions.question: First, a clear, colourless liquid with the chemical formula CHCl3. The Scottish physician Sir James Simpson pioneered its use as an anaesthetic in 1847.
Second, a substance such as magnesium hydroxide or calcium carbonate that is used to counteract or neutralise potentially harmful stomach secretions.
Finally, a chemical messenger such as dopamine or serotonin. These allow impulses to be passed from one cell to the next throughout the nervous system.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer

questions.question: Which Hindu text was an inspiration for Schopenhauer's The World As Will And Representation? These scriptures conclude the Vedas and take their name from the Sanskrit for the act of sitting down beside.

Next, Schopenhauer likened the suffering of daily life to that of which Greek mythological character, a king of the Lapiths in Thessaly, who is bound to a perpetually spinning, fiery wheel after attempting to seduce Hera?
Finally, which composer incorporated Schopenhauer's themes of earthly renunciation and transcendence into works including Parsifal and Tristan And Isolde?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a biblical prophet

questions.question: First, according to the final verses of the Book of Malachi, which prophet would be sent before the day of the Lord? In observances of the Passover, a place is regularly set for him.
The first Book of Kings tells of Elijah's triumph over the prophets of Baal at which mountain in Israel? It gives its name to a mendicant order of the Roman Catholic Church.

Elijah prophesied the downfall of which Queen, the wife of King Ahab, who had initiated the worship of Baal in Israel? The prophecy came true when she was later defenestrated and her body eaten by dogs.

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: You just saw Tokyo and Kyoto, names that include the character kyo, meaning capital. Your picture bonuses are three maps showing prefectures whose names have an element in common, for example, kawa, meaning river. Five points for each element you can name. These prefectures have names that all contain what four letter element?
Second, I need the four letter element common to these prefectures.
Finally, what element links the names of these prefectures?

bonuses.topic: on prominent thinkers whose surnames appear within other words or names. For example, the surname of the philosopher David Hume appears within that of the comedian Amy Schumer. The answer in each case is a single surname

questions.question: First, the name of which 20th century psychoanalyst appears in the name of a lobe-finned bony fish thought to be extinct until 1938, when one was discovered in the Indian Ocean?
Second, the name of which German philosopher appears within the full name of a mathematician of the Kerala school, credited with developing an inverse tangent series for the approximation of pi?
questions.answer: Immanuel Kant (The mathematician is Nilakantha Somayaji.)

questions.question: Finally, the name of which English empiricist appears in the name of a percussion instrument whose name means set of bells in German?

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, then, Christ Church, three questions on relativistic mechanics

questions.question: In a ratio relating to the rest mass of a particle and its mass when travelling at velocity v, the Greek letter gamma is used to represent a factor named after which Dutch physicist and Nobel laureate, born...?
What is the value of gamma for a particle whose velocity is c times the hyperbolic tangent of theta? Give your answer in terms of theta.
Finally, what is the value of gamma for a particle whose velocity is c times the sign of theta?

bonuses.topic: on musical performers named in the subtitle of Angela Davis's work Blues Legacies And Black Feminism. Name each person from the description

questions.question: First, born in Georgia in 1886, a singer known as the Mother of the Blues. Her noted recordings include CC Rider and Prove It On Me.
Born in Chattanooga, her recordings include Down Hearted Blues and 'Tain't Nobody's Bizness If I Do. Her death in 1937 was the subject of a play by Edward Albee.
Finally, born in 1915, a jazz singer nicknamed Lady Day, with whom the song Strange Fruit is most associated.

bonuses.topic: Opera/Ballet

questions.question: You heard a moment ago what is, of course, a pas de deux from Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake. And for your bonuses, you will hear three further pas de deux from well-known ballets. In each case, I would like the name of the ballet. Firstly...
Secondly, this 2011 ballet.
questions.answer: Alice's Adventures In Wonderland by Joby Talbot

questions.question: And finally...
questions.answer: Romeo And Juliet by Sergei Prokofiev

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, then, Manchester, three questions on blue plaques in North Staffordshire

questions.question: A plaque in Leek commemorates Lady Elizabeth Wardle, a skilled embroiderer and a leading figure in the local silk industry. From 1885 she supervised the creation of a replica of which artwork, probably commissioned in the 1070s?
A plaque at the Harecastle Tunnel in Kidsgrove mentions the engineer James Brindley. Born in 1716, he's best known for construction achievements in what form of transport?
Finally, a blue plaque at the home ground of Port Vale Football Club in Burslem marks Ian Fraser Kilmister, a founder of which rock band in 1975? Known as Lemmy, he died in 2015.

bonuses.topic: on short stories by Jorge Luis Borges, published in the collection Labyrinths

questions.question: One story in the collection describes a society in which every aspect of daily life is dictated by a lottery run by a shadowy company. This society shares its name with which major city of the ancient world?

Another story describes a cabal of intellectuals called Orbis Tertius, who set out to invent first a country and then an entire imaginary world. Name either of these fictional places. Both are named along with...
Which Islamic polymath is the subject of a story by Borges that imagines his difficulties in translating Aristotle's Poetics, due to...?

bonuses.topic: on a political writer

questions.question: Quote, "On my arrival in the United States, "I was struck by the degree of ability among the governed "and the lack of it among the governing." These words are from Democracy In America, by which 19th century political writer and historian?

Another quote now. "When a nation abolishes aristocracy, "centralisation follows as a matter of course." These words appear in an 1856 work by de Tocqueville. Its title mentions what French political system that ended in 1789?
Finally, de Tocqueville lost all his political offices for refusing to take an oath of loyalty to the regime of which political figure, who had seized power in a coup of 1851?

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: You just saw Bernini's Aeneas, Anchises, And Ascanius. Your bonuses are three more 17th century artistic portrayals of the legend of Aeneas. Five points for each artist you can name. First, this French artist.
Next, this Italian artist.
Finally, this French artist.

bonuses.topic: Your bonuses, then, Manchester, three questions on industrial catalysts

questions.question: First, what metallic element is commonly suspended on activated carbon for the catalysis of the hydrogenation of alkenes?

Next, which group of aluminosilicate materials are commonly used as catalysts? Some applications include hydrocracking in the petrochemical industry and ion exchange beds in commercial water purification.
Finally, which metal did Haber cite as a primary catalyst in the manufacture of ammonia in his book, The Thermodynamics Of Technical Gas Reactions?

bonuses.topic: on South American cities that take their names from cities in Spain. Name each from the description

questions.question: First, a large city in north central Argentina. It was founded in 1573 by Cabrera, who named it after a city in Andalusia, around 120km north-east of Seville...

Secondly, a port in northwest Colombia, the capital of Bolivar Department, and the country's chief oil port. Pedro de Heredia founded it in 1533 and named it after a port in Murcia, which today is a major naval base.

Finally, a city in northern Venezuela that was briefly the country's capital after it separated from Gran Colombia. It was founded by Alonso Diaz Moreno, who named it after his home city, now Spain's third most populous.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Japanese costume designer Emi Wada

questions.question: First, Wada's work with which British film director includes costume design for the films Prospero's Books, The Pillow Book, and 8½ Women?

In 1992 Wada collaborated with which director on an Emmy winning production of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex? This director's other works include the original Broadway production of The Lion King, for which she became the first woman to win the Tony Award for Best Director of a Musical.

Finally, Wada also designed costumes for two films by Zhang Yimou - 2002's Hero and which other wuxia film? Zhang Ziyi plays the blind dancer Mei, believed to be a member of the rebel group named in the film's title.
questions.answer: House Of Flying Daggers 十面埋伏

bonuses.topic: three questions on trains in art

questions.question: First, small black steam trains are a recurring background element in the metaphysical paintings of which Italian artist, born in 1888?

Born in Sao Paulo in 1886, the works of which key figure in Brazilian Modernism include several paintings of Brazil's developing rail network in her characteristic style of simplified geometric compositions and bright flat colours?
Finally, depicting a steam locomotive emerging from a fireplace in an empty room, Time Transfixed is a work of 1938 by which surrealist painter?

bonuses.topic: on French literary cycles

questions.question: After a royal dynasty, what alternative name is given to the body of medieval French literature that is also known as the Matter of France?
After two intertwined families, what name is given to the cycle of works by Zola...?
Finally, what name is commonly given to the entire output of Honore de Balzac's literary career from the 1820s, often...?
questions.answer: La Comédie humaine (or The Human Comedy)

bonuses.topic: on styles of musical composition. In each case, I want you to name the musical style or form from the description

questions.question: First, originally a court dance performed in the 16th century and with a name meaning "from Padua", compositions in this style are slow and in duple or quadruple time.
Originally a style of folk dance named for the historical region surrounding Warsaw, compositions in this style are lively and...

Finally, originally a style of music associated with Venetian gondoliers, compositions in this style are typically in 6/8 time. Notable examples include Belle Nuit, O Nuit D'amour from Offenbach's 1881 opera The Tales Of Hoffmann.

bonuses.topic: on language families

questions.question: First, its validity sometimes criticised, the proposed Pama-Nyungan family comprises the majority of languages native to which large country?
The Na-Dene languages are native to western and north-western parts of which continent?
Two of the six languages currently recognised as classical languages of India are part of the Indo-European family. The other four belong to which other family?
questions.answer: Dravidian (The four languages are Telugu, Tamil, Kannada, and Malayalam.)

bonuses.topic: World History

questions.question: Following on from that map of the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989, in which hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil were released into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Alaska, for your bonuses, Christ Church, you'll see three further locations of oil spills. In each case, give the name by which the incident is usually known. First, this spill of 1967.
Secondly, this deliberate 1991 event.
And finally, this major spill of 2010.

bonuses.topic: on the Harvard Computers, a group of influential female astronomers originally hired to process images and data taken by the Harvard Observatory in the late 19th century

questions.question: First of all, in 1901, which of the Harvard Computers published the system of classifying stars into spectral classes by colour or temperature that starts O-B-A-F-G-K...?

Next, which other astronomer who worked as a computer in the 1880s added to Cannon's scheme by including classifications based on the width of the star's spectral lines? She also became the first person to calculate the orbit of a spectroscopic binary.
Finally, who discovered the period luminosity function that governed Cepheid variables?

bonuses.topic: three questions on mythological triads

questions.question: With a name meaning "Great Queen" or "Phantom Queen", which figure in Irish mythology is variously depicted as a triple-aspected war goddess or a trio of sisters named Badb, Macha, and Nemain or Anand?

In Hinduism, the Tridevi are three major goddesses linked to the three male deities referred to as the Trimurti. They are Lakshmi, Parvati, and which other, the Goddess of learning, arts and music, and the wife of Brahma?
Finally, in Greek mythology, the three sisters Clotho, Lachesis and Atropos are collectively known by what name?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a two-word term

questions.question: In a 2007 book subtitled The Impact Of The Highly Improbable, what term did Nassim Nicholas Taleb popularise to indicate a rare, unpredictable event that has extreme consequences?
Next, an early use of the phrase "black swan" to refer to something vanishingly rare occurs in the satires of which Roman poet, active in the later first century CE.
Finally, what is the name of the Black Swan antagonist in Tchaikovsky's Ballet Swan Lake? She seeks to lure Prince Siegfried away from the white swan heroine Odette.

bonuses.topic: three questions on geology

questions.question: Feldspar is an example of what important class of minerals? Their fundamental unit is a tetrahedron of the two most common elements in the Earth's crust.
Which potassium-rich feldspar defines level six on the Mohs scale of hardness that is harder than apatite, but softer than quartz?
Finally, containing aluminium and cleaving in thin sheets, which group of silicate minerals includes biotypes and muscovites?

bonuses.topic: Opera/Ballet

questions.question: Well, a moment ago you heard an extract from the 1894 opera Thais based on a novel by Anatole France. Your music bonuses are three more operatic works inspired by French literature, though the composer in each case is not French. First, name the composer of this late-20th-century operatic overture.
questions.answer: Philip Glass (The excerpt is from Les Enfants Terribles, adapted from a novel by Cocteau.)

questions.question: Second, the composer of this extract.
Finally, the composer of this piece, first performed in 1893.
questions.answer: Giacomo Puccini (The excerpt is from Manon Lescaut, based on a 1731 novel by Abbe Prevost.)

bonuses.topic: three questions on medieval Wales

questions.question: First noted for a victory over the Vikings in 856, Rhodri, known as the Great, succeeded his father Merfyn the Freckled as ruler of which kingdom in 844?
A grandson of Rhodri prominently associated with the codification of Welsh law, Hywel ap Cadell is usually known by what short byname? You may answer in English or Welsh.
questions.answer: Hywel Dda or Hywel the Good

questions.question: Finally, Rhodri and Hywel also ruled which kingdom of north central Wales? Its name survives in that of the large present-day county...

bonuses.topic: three questions on paintings in the Manchester Art Gallery

questions.question: A Dream of Annesley Hall by Edward Matthew Ward depicts the early love of which Romantic poet? He appears grim-faced and standing in darkness as he looks through a window at a party.
In the 1874 work Byron's Dream, a young man and woman on a hillside view an approaching horseman. This painting is by which artist, associated with the pre-Raphaelites?
Also inspired by Byron, another work by Brown depicts brothers confined in a dungeon by Lake Geneva. I need the word that completes its title, The Prisoner of...what island castle?

bonuses.topic: on a scientist

questions.question: Born in 1805, which Irish mathematician gives his name to a function used in quantum mechanics to express the total energy of a system in terms of its momentum and positional coordinates?

Devised by Hamilton in 1843 in an extension of the principles of complex numbers, what name is given to numbers in the form a + bi + cj + dk, where a, b, c and d are real numbers, and i, j and k are unit vectors in the x, y and z directions?
Finally, in his work on quaternions, Hamilton also coined which six-letter term now widely used in mathematics to denote quantities that have magnitude but not direction?

bonuses.topic: Link

questions.question: That was the astronaut Michael Collins, who was awarded the National Geographic Society's Hubbard Medal in 1970 for his part in the first moon landing. And for your bonuses, Open, you need to identify three more recipients of this medal. First, this oceanographer pictured on the right, next to his father, in front of the bathyscaphe they designed.
Secondly, this polar explorer.
Finally...

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Japanese Edo period playwright Chikamatsu

questions.question: Born in 1653, Chikamatsu is best known for his works in what genre of Japanese theatre that features puppetry accompanied by shamisen music?
Next, The Battles of Coxinga follows the life of the titular Chinese general who established the kingdom of Tungning, a Han Chinese state, on which island?
Many of Chikamatsu's later plays were both set and premiered in which city, currently the third largest in Japan, where he lived and worked?

bonuses.topic: on the first chemical elements discovered through spectroscopy

questions.question: First, in 1860 and 1861, Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff used their newly invented spectroscope to discover which two highly reactive group one metals? Both are named after the colours of their respective emission spectrums.

In 1861, William Crookes discovered which group 13 metal through spectroscopic analysis of impure sulphuric acid? A soft silvery-white metal, its soluble salts are highly toxic and have historically been used as rat poisons and insecticides.

Finally, also named after the colour of its emission spectrum, which other group 13 metal was discovered in 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymus Richter? Reich believed he had found a sulphide of a new element in a sample of zinc ore, but was colour-blind, and so had to enlist Richter to analyse it spectroscopically.

bonuses.topic: three questions on ancient history

questions.question: Dating to the fifth century BC, the document known as The Old Oligarch forms a written constitution of the civilisation centred on which city?

Laws known by a Greek term meaning "shaking off of burdens" were introduced by which Athenian writer and lawmaker?

bonuses.topic: three questions on German cities named after people

questions.question: Founded as a Roman colony and named after an early Roman emperor, which city north-west of Munich, was the headquarters of the Fugger and Welser merchant families from the later Middle Ages?
One of the most popular cities of Saxony, along with Dresden and Leipzig, which industrial centre was known as Karl-Marx-Stadt from 1953 to 1990?

bonuses.topic: on the tentative list of proposed new UNESCO World Heritage sites in the UK, revealed by the UK government in April, 2023

questions.question: First, named for the large town in which it is located, which public park on the Wirral is on the 2023 list? Designed by Joseph Paxton, it is generally agreed to be the world's first publicly funded park and notably influenced Central Park in New York City.

Second, the list also includes the marine parks and protected areas of the Little island of which British Overseas Territory? The first MPAs were designated around 35 years ago to protect the islands' reefs, mangroves and seagrass beds and now cover around 75% of the island's shoreline.
Also on the list, the Flow Country is a large rolling expanse of blanket bog, a globally rare habitat, that spans which two adjacent historic counties of Scotland, the most northerly on the mainland?

bonuses.topic: on films whose titles contain the full name of a character - for example, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. In each case, all I need to hear for the points is that character's name

questions.question: First, a 1973 film by Chantal Akerman, the title character is a lonely, widowed housewife who occasionally engages in sex work.

Secondly, a 1972 film by Rainer Werner Fassbinder. The title character is a narcissistic fashion designer who becomes infatuated with a young model while in a sadomasochistic relationship with her assistant.

Finally, the English title of a 1974 film by Werner Herzog. Based on a true story, the title character is a young man who appears one day in Nuremberg, barely able to speak or walk, having spent his life up to that point imprisoned in a cellar by an unknown captor.

bonuses.topic: three questions on genetics

questions.question: Based on studies in the fruit fly Drosophila, which US scientists concluded that genes are arranged in a series on chromosomes and are responsible for heredity? He won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1933.

The US scientists George Beadle and Edward Tatum proposed what hypothesis based on findings that specific amino acids needed to be added to growth medium to culture some mutant strains of the mould Neurospora crassa?

Finally, Marshall Nirenberg and Heinrich Matthaei first cracked the genetic code when they established that RNA containing a chain of uracil coded for which essential amino acid? It is a precursor for the amino acid tyrosine.

bonuses.topic: World Geography

questions.question: The 1842 Treaty of Nanking ended the first Opium War and forced China to open five treaty ports in which outside powers could trade while their citizens remained exempt from local law. Second, this provincial capital.
And finally...

bonuses.topic: on the Rijksmuseum Gallery of Honour, a collection of particularly notable works from the Dutch Golden Age

questions.question: First, born in Leiden in 1626, which genre painter's works in the gallery include The Merry Family, a typically busy comic domestic scene with a moralising slant?

Next, one of the first women included in the gallery, which painter was represented by a still life with flowers in a glass vase? The daughter of a botanist, she's renowned for her precise, vivid depictions of flowers and insects, usually against dark backgrounds.

Finally, born in Antwerp in the 1580s, which painter's works in the gallery include a militiaman holding a Berkemeyer, a portrait of a cheerful, florid-cheeked soldier raising a glass of beer in a toast?

bonuses.topic: three questions on anarchists

Next, the French anarchist Emilienne Morin was the partner of which revolutionary killed in the Battle of Madrid in 1936? She served in his eponymous column, or military unit, a leading anarchist force in the early part of the Spanish Civil War.
Which two Italian-born anarchists were executed for murder in Massachusetts in 1927 after a controversial trial believed by many to have been political?

bonuses.topic: on garden biodiversity, using information from the Royal Horticultural Society website. In each case, give the common name of the arthropod from the description

questions.question: First, the RHS describes which soil-dwelling predatory animal as part of a healthy garden ecosystem? Belonging to the class Chilopoda, they have one pair of legs per body segment and are often brown or yellowish in colour with prominent antennae.
A harmless terrestrial crustacean often found in compost heaps, where they help break down plant material, they have numerous local names such as slater, pill bug and chuggy pig.
Finally, a predatory insect of the order Coleoptera that helps control aphids. The colourful seven-spot is the most common species in the UK.

bonuses.topic: Pop Music

Finally, this saxophonist.

bonuses.topic: three questions on a poem and its sources

questions.question: Boccaccio's Il Filostrato is widely accepted as a primary source for which long narrative poem by Geoffrey Chaucer? Chaucer's poem, in its turn, was a source for a late tragedy by Shakespeare.

Book four of Troilus and Criseyde includes a long monologue by Troilus on free will and predestination absent from Boccaccio's poem. Its source is instead agreed to be which sixth century work by Boethius, which Chaucer had translated in the 1380s?

bonuses.topic: three questions on holidays and festivals of Britain and Ireland

bonuses.topic: Biology

A polysaccharide consisting of branching chains of glucose molecules that is the main form in which the carbohydrate is stored in higher animals. Insulin stimulates its production in the liver and muscles.
A disaccharide that, on hydrolysis by the enzyme invertase, is broken down into its constituent monosaccharides, fructose and glucose.

bonuses.topic: Drama

questions.question: That was, of course, Titus Andronicus, pictured with his daughter, Lavinia, in the Globe's 2014 production. For your bonuses, UCL, you'll see three further photos of productions of Shakespeare's Roman plays. In each case, simply name the play. Firstly.
Secondly.
And finally.

Who was on the English throne at the time of the attempted Mongol invasions of Japan?
Finally, who was on the British throne at the fall of the Tokugawa shogunate?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon

questions.question: Three questions for you on a sociologist. Which Canadian-born sociologist is credited with developing the dramaturgical theory of human interaction in his 1959 book, The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life?

What term is coined by Goffman for institutions such as prisons and mental hospitals in which people are bureaucratically processed, cut off from outside influence and their behaviour is regulated, regimented and monitored?
Which 1964 work by Goffman examines the reaction of society to individuals with characteristics that deviate from the perceived norm?

bonuses.topic: Pop Music

questions.question: That was Autobahn by Kraftwerk, recorded and engineered in the studio of producer Conny Plank, who helped shape the sound of several influential groups of the so-called Krautrock scene, as well as the new wave bands that follow them. For your bonuses, three more pieces produced by Plank. In each case, I want the name of the group for five points. Firstly, this German group, of which Plank was said to be the unofficial third member.
Secondly, this other German group with which Plank worked extensively.
Finally, this British group.

bonuses.topic: on bossa nova

questions.question: Which Brazilian singer was known as the voice of bossa nova? She shot to stardom with the 1963 recording of the song The Girl From Ipanema, from an album recorded with the saxophonist Stan Getz and her husband, Joao?
Next, the music for The Girl From Ipanema was written by which Brazilian musician, composer and pioneer of bossa nova?

Jobim, along with Luiz Bonfa, contributed to the soundtrack to which 1959 film that won the Palme d'Or? The Bonfa composition, Manha de Carnaval, from its soundtrack contributed to the early global popularity of bossa nova.

bonuses.topic: three questions on the wildlife of Trinidad and Tobago

questions.question: First, bright red in colour and with a long, thin bill, which mangrove-dwelling wading bird appears on the coat of arms of Trinidad and Tobago?
Secondly, known locally as the quenk, what pig-like animal of the family Tayassuidae is found throughout Central and South America?
Found in Trinidad's rainforest hills, what is the common name of Leopardus pardalis? A nocturnal, solitary and territorial wildcat of medium size, with markings similar to a leopard or jaguar.

bonuses.topic: questions on power series in mathematics

questions.question: Born in 1698, which Scottish mathematician gives his name to the Taylor series of a function expanded about the reference point zero, whose terms consist of the variable X raised to non-negative integer powers?

Similar to a Maclaurin series, what series, named after a 19th-century French mathematician, denotes the generalised Taylor series whose terms consist of the variable X raised to integer powers of either sign?
In the 1890s, which French-born mathematician developed a method of approximating a function by writing it as the ratio of two distinct power series?

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: That was The Mule Track by Paul Nash, who was one of the many artists commissioned as an official war artist by the British Government during the First World War. For your bonuses, Manchester, you will see works by three further war artists. In each case, simply name the artist. Firstly...
Secondly, this artist, one of the first women commissioned.
Finally, this artist who was an official war artist during the Second World War.

bonuses.topic: on treaties of London. In each case, please give the decade that saw the signing of the treaty described

questions.question: First, the two treaties of London, signed a year apart, that resulted in a temporary truce after the Battle of Poitiers during the Edwardian phase of the Hundred Years War.
Secondly, the Treaty of London that guaranteed the independence and neutrality of Belgium soon after it became independent.
Finally, the Treaty of London that tried to prevent further hostilities in the Balkans. This effort proved unsuccessful after Bulgaria attacked its former allies, Greece and Serbia.

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: Your three bonuses then, Manchester, are questions on the visual arts. From the Greek for "to transform", what name is given to the perspective technique in art that gives either a distorted or normal image of a subject, depending on one's viewpoint?
Which Swiss artist has created a number of 21st-century anamorphic installations, including Three Ellipses For Three Locks, in Cardiff, and Across The Buildings, at King's Cross in London?
Finally, Jean de Dinteville and Georges de Selve appear in which 1533 painting by Hans Holbein the Younger, whose depiction of a skull in the foreground is a well-known example of anamorphosis?

bonuses.topic: on star formation

questions.question: Which British physicist gives his name to the critical length and mass scales that determine whether or not a molecular cloud can collapse to form a star? He's also known for his work on the classical formulation of black-body radiation.

Along with Hermann von Helmholtz, which British physicist names the mechanism of gravitational contraction that heats young stars before they can sustain nuclear fusion? He's better known for his work in thermodynamics.

Which British astronomer derived a limit for the maximum luminosity of a star, where the radiation pressure from the star equals the gravitational force exerted by it? He's also known for an experiment that confirmed the predictions of general relativity.

bonuses.topic: onstage representations of the mythological figure Phaedra

questions.question: An early stage version of the Phaedra story, Hippolytus is a play by which ancient Greek playwright?
First performed in 1677, Phedre is a tragedy by which French playwright?
Finally, which British playwright wrote the 1996 play Phaedra's Love?

bonuses.topic: European History

questions.question: Three bonuses on the 18th-century author and abolitionist Olaudah Equiano. After being bought by a Royal Navy officer at a young age, Equiano was named after Gustav, the Swedish king who founded what dynasty in 1523?

bonuses.topic: on English county towns. In each case, name the county town that lies closest to the midpoint of a straight line drawn on the map between the two named locations

questions.question: First, Oxford and Truro. This town is associated with the Monmouth Rebellion of 1685, and is the location of a first class county cricket ground.
Second, Gloucester and Oakham. The royal favourite Piers Gaveston was imprisoned at the prominent castle here, and killed nearby in 1312.
Finally, Northampton and Ipswich. Oliver Cromwell's skull is said to be buried here.

bonuses.topic: on a poem, Imperial

questions.question: First published in 1842, which dramatic monologue by Robert Browning is addressed by a nobleman to a visitor to his home, as they stand before a painting of the title?

The text of My Last Duchess is typically prefaced with an epigraph naming which city northeast of Bologna? The poem's narrator is usually assumed to be the fifth and final duke of this city, Alfonso II d'Este.
The Last Duchess herself is usually equated with Alfonso's first wife, Lucrezia, a member of which Italian political dynasty that held power in Tuscany from the 15th to 17th centuries?

bonuses.topic: three questions on concrete

questions.question: The two main components of concrete are a binder, such as cement, and a particulate material, such as sand or gravel. What general term is used in construction and engineering to denote the latter?

In the early 19th century, the inventor Joseph Aspdin developed a form of cement manufactured from limestone and clay or shale that remains in wide use today. It takes its name from which tied island in the English Channel, known for its limestone?

Finally, the process of maintaining optimal moisture and temperature conditions while concrete is setting is known by what term? In cookery, the same term refers broadly to methods of food preservation.

bonuses.topic: three questions on Asia in the 1890s

questions.question: The Paknam Incident of 1893 saw French warships blockade the capital of which country, forcing its rulers to cede substantial territories to the east of the Mekong River?
Taking place in a client state in 1894, the Tonghak Rebellion sparked a war between which two Asian powers?
From 1892, the organisation known as Katipunan opposed colonial rule in which present day country? It declared independence from Spain in 1898.

bonuses.topic: World History

questions.question: That was the first flag of Gran Colombia, a South American state that existed between 1819 and 1831. For your bonuses, you will see three further flags of states that no longer exist. Five points for each you can identify. Firstly, this empire that came to an end when its government was replaced by a Soviet-backed junta.
Secondly, this flag belonged to which federation, in existence from 1958 to 1962?
And finally, which former European kingdom is this?

bonuses.topic: Mathematics

questions.question: Imperial, you get three questions on graph theory. A complete planar graph comprises a set of nodes all joined to each other, but with no lines crossing. What is the maximum number of nodes in this type of graph?
Born in 1930, which Dutch mathematician gave his name to an algorithm to find the path of least weight between any two nodes of a graph?
The seven bridges in which city on the River Pregel are often cited to show that not all graphs have closed trails, that use each...?

bonuses.topic: European History

questions.question: OK, your bonuses, Lincoln, are three questions on Roman history. First, while holding the public office of quaestor, which statesman delivered a series of speeches in a trial condemning Gaius Verres in 70 BC?
To what position was Cicero elected in 66 BC? It was directly above quaestor and aedile on the Roman cursus honorum, or ladder of offices.
To what more senior position, equivalent to the Chief Magistrate of Rome, was Cicero elected in 63 BC?

bonuses.topic: on astronomy

questions.question: What three-word name is given to the class of highly energetic astronomical objects that includes quasars, blazars and BL Lacertae objects?
Which class of active galactic nuclei, bright in the infrared, is named after the US astronomer who discovered them?
Finally, the engine that powers active galactic nuclei is believed to centre on what large, dense objects surrounded by an accretion disk and a torus of dust and gas?

bonuses.topic: questions on swords

questions.question: Born in Mecca in about 600, who is the last of the four rightly guided caliphs, the first imam in Shia Islam, and the owner of the Zulfiqar double-edged sword, one of the most celebrated items in Islamic...?
According to The Song of Roland, during which battle of 778 did Roland carry Durandal, whose pommel was said to contain several Christian relics?
Having a short curved blade with a sickle-like protrusion, harpe was used by which mythological hero to decapitate the Gorgon Medusa?

bonuses.topic: on prison scenes in Shakespeare's plays. In each case give the title of the play from the description of the scene

questions.question: First, Claudio is visited in prison by his sister, Isabella, who tells him that the Duke's deputy, Angelo, has made him an offer - Claudio's freedom in exchange for her virginity. To Isabella's horror, Claudio begs her to accept.
Secondly, Borachio and Conrad are brought before the sexton by bumbling constable Dogberry. They're accused of staging a dangerous piece of lechery on behalf of Don John.
Finally, Paulina visits the prison in which Queen Hermione is being held. She learns that while imprisoned, the queen has given birth to a daughter whom she determines to bring before King Leontes.

bonuses.topic: Opera/Ballet

questions.question: That was an extract from The Seven Deadly Sins by Kurt Weill, a sung - or opera - ballet that premiered in Paris in 1933. For your bonuses, you'll hear three further recordings, all of operas that premiered in the 1930s. Name the composer in each case. First, the composer of this opera, which premiered in an incomplete version in 1937.
Secondly, this composer, who died in 1928. The opera premiered in 1930.
And finally, the composer of this opera, which premiered in 1934.

bonuses.topic: three questions on Members of Parliament for Northampton

questions.question: Despite repeated re-election, from 1880 to 1886, Charles Bradlaugh was denied his seat in Parliament as MP for Northampton because he refused to swear a religious oath. He was president of what organisation which he had founded in 1866?
Briefly MP for Northampton in the early 1920s, who became Britain's first female cabinet minister when Ramsay MacDonald appointed her Minister of Labour in 1929?
Known as Little P, who became MP for Northampton in 1796, serving until his sudden death in the House of Commons in May 1812?

bonuses.topic: on radiation

questions.question: Measured in curies or becquerels, which measure of radiation counts the number of atomic decays per unit time?
Measured in grays or rads, what measure of radiation exposure counts the amount of energy imparted on matter per unit mass? I need a two-word term.
Finally, measured in sieverts in the SI system, what measure of overall radiation exposure weights the absorbed dose by factors related to the sensitivity to radiation of the bodily organs affected?

bonuses.topic: on eponymous terms in chemistry

questions.question: The name of which French chemist is given to the principle which states that when a change in conditions is applied to a system in equilibrium, the system will adjust in order to counteract the change?

Which Swiss-born chemist formulated the law that states the following? If a reaction can take place by more than one route from the same initial and final conditions, then the total enthalpy change is the same for each route.
What name is given to the constant that is used to represent the number of atoms or molecules in one mole of a substance? It can be represented by the letter L for Lima.

bonuses.topic: on Jacobean tragedies, Imperial

questions.question: First published in 1633, Tis Pity She's A Whore is a revenge drama by which playwright, also known for his collaboration with Thomas Dekker and William Rowley on The Witch Of Edmonton?

D'Anville, an amoral French nobleman, is the title character of which 1611 tragedy by Cyril Tourneur? At the end of the play, he kills himself accidentally while trying to execute his nephew, an event presented as a vindication of divine judgment.
Which tragedy by John Webster includes a murder scene incorporating a poisoned Bible, a melancholy duke who believes himself a wolf and a deception involving wax figures and a severed hand?

bonuses.topic: three questions on paintings of the Arctic

questions.question: Depicting a jagged mass of ice with a ship wrecked against its right-hand slope, The Sea Of Ice is an 1824 work by which German romantic painter?
Next, which artist of the Hudson River School painted the 1865 work Aurora Borealis, based on a sketch and description by the Arctic explorer Isaac Israel Hayes?

Inspired by John Franklin's lost Arctic expedition, Man Proposes, God Disposes is an 1864 painting by which British artist? It depicts two polar bears picking over scattered wreckage, one with a mouthful of human bones.

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: Your picture starter, Imperial, was Claude Lorrain's Seaport At Sunset. For your picture bonuses, three more paintings of ports or harbours. Five points for identifying the artist of each. First...
Secondly...
And finally...

bonuses.topic: on 20th century history. In each case, I need a precise year. All three questions have a five word clue to a year that ends in the number 5

questions.question: First, miracle year of Albert Einstein.
Secondly, Japan bans socialism and communism?
Finally, Moscow Metro opens under Stalin?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a canid mammal

questions.question: First, the Japanese raccoon dog, binomial Nyctereutes viverrinus, is also commonly known by what single word Japanese name? These animals often appear in Japanese folklore as shapeshifting trickster figures.

Directed by Isao Takahata, which 1994 Studio Ghibli film centres on a community of tanuki who are trying to save their forest home from destruction? Its title refers to the sound produced by the tanuki inflating and drumming on their bellies.
Finally, an anthropomorphic tanuki called Tom Nook is a major recurring character in which series of social simulation video games? Subtitles of recent instalments include New Leaf and...?

bonuses.topic: on Iran

questions.question: The power of the Shah was strengthened, following the US and British-backed coup of 1953 that removed which prime minister from power?
In 1963, the Shah launched an aggressive reform programme that saw the dismantling of Iran's traditional land ownership structures. What colour is used to designate this...?
Which Iranian leader was the third president of the Islamic...?

bonuses.topic: three questions on a Swiss Nobel Laureate

questions.question: Born in 1828, which Swiss humanitarian was a co-founder of the Red Cross and won the first Nobel Peace Prize together with Frederic Passy?
Dunant's humanitarian work began in reaction to the human cost of which battle of 1859? It took place in the Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia as part of the Second Italian War of Independence.

In which year did Dunant win the first Nobel Peace Prize? The ceremony took place five years after the death of Alfred Nobel. The same year saw the deaths of President William McKinley and Queen Victoria.

bonuses.topic: Other Art

questions.question: Your three bonuses, Aberdeen, are questions on the Glasgow School of Art. What was the surname of the influential artists Margaret and Frances, active at the Glasgow School of Art from the 1890s? Together with their husbands Charles Rennie Mackintosh and Herbert McNair, they were known as The Four, or, from their sometimes macabre themes, as the Spook School.
In 1894, Jessie Newbery became head of which department within the school associated with textiles? She is credited with raising its status to that of a creative artform.
Finally, born in 1970, which graduate of the school is noted for her focus on the female nude? Her works include Strategy, Stare, Blue Pieta and Torso.

bonuses.topic: on words in Shakespeare. The answer in each case is a football club that played in the Premier League in 2022-'23

questions.question: First, give the name of the club that begins with this five-letter word. In Antony And Cleopatra, Charmion says she would rather heat this with drinking than with love, and in Troilus And Cressida, Cassandra likens spotted ones to polluted offerings.
The first five letters of a name of which Premier League club spell a word that appears in Hamlet's "to be or not to be" speech in a now somewhat archaic sense of limit, terminus or frontier?
Finally, which club's name begins with the direction in which Olivia points Viola in Act III of Twelfth Night?

bonuses.topic: Chemistry

questions.question: For your picture starter you saw a diagram showing the experimental set-up for a simple distillation. Your picture bonuses will be three more diagrams showing the experimental set-ups for common techniques or methods in chemistry. Name the technique or method in each case. Firstly...
Secondly...
Finally...

bonuses.topic: Biology

questions.question: Your three bonuses, Aberdeen, are questions on proteins. Proteins that contain a mitochondrial targeting sequence can enter the mitochondria through the T-O-M or Tom40 pore in the outer mitochondrial membrane. Here, 40 refers to the molecular mass of this protein and is measured in what units?

The SAM or SAM complex is responsible for inserting what general class of membrane proteins into mitochondria? In contrast to alpha-helical membrane proteins, they are made up of anti-parallel strands.

The MIA pathway allows targeting of proteins from the cytosol into the region between the outer membrane and the inner membrane of the mitochondria. This region is known as the IMS. For what do these letters stand?

bonuses.topic: three questions, Sheffield, on Japanese straits in history

questions.question: The Shimonoseki campaign was a 19th-century conflict between Japan and Western powers over control of the strait separating which two Japanese islands? It is also known as the Kanmon Straits.

Also taking place in the Kanmon Straits, the Battle of Dan-no-ura was the final battle of the Genpei War. This ended the Heian period and installed the first shogun. It occurred towards the end of which century?
Finally, the name for the straits between Japan and Korea in which it was fought, the 1905 Battle of Tsushima was a major Japanese victory against which country?

bonuses.topic: on economic DSGE models

questions.question: The letter S in DSGE models stands for what word, intended to take into account random shocks and fluctuations present in an economy?

Dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models updated the neoclassical RBC theory, which explained macroeconomic fluctuations with technical shocks and productivity changes, allowing the economy to respond to changes rationally. For what do the letters RBC stand?
DSGE and RBC models have origins in theories explained in the 1874 work Elements Of Pure Economics by which French economist?

bonuses.topic: three questions on works by the US film-maker Mike Flanagan

questions.question: Flanagan's 2020 mini series The Haunting Of Bly Manor is a loose modern adaptation of which novella of 1898? Victoria Pedretti plays an au pair hired by a wealthy family to look after their children, Miles and Flora.

Which 2016 horror film by Flanagan stars Kate Siegel as a deaf and mute writer living in an isolated forest cabin where she's attacked by a masked killer? The larger part of the film takes place without dialogue.

What word precedes both "mass" and "club" in the titles of series of 2021 and 2022 by Flanagan? The former is a vampire story set in an isolated Catholic fishing community, the latter is based on the young adult horror novels of Christopher Pike.

bonuses.topic: Classical Music

questions.question: You heard a moment ago Brahms' Academic Festival Overture, written as a tribute to the University of Breslau in 1880. Your music bonuses are three more pieces from the late 19th century, written as gifts, this time to individuals such as family members or pupils. Five points for each composer you can name. First, this composer.
Secondly, this Western European composer.
Finally, this British composer.

bonuses.topic: questions on a mathematician

questions.question: Born in 1882, whom did Albert Einstein describe as the most significant creative mathematical genius thus far produced since the higher education of women began? She has also been described as the mother of modern algebra.

In 1915, David Hilbert invited Noether to join which German university to the south of Hanover, described as one of the great mathematical centres of the world? Gauss, Riemann and Landau have all held faculty positions there.
In physics, Noether's theorem linked symmetries in the laws of nature to conserved quantities. Time translation symmetry is connected via Noether's theorem to the conservation of which quantity?

bonuses.topic: three questions on the Elizabethan navigator Martin Frobisher

questions.question: First, during one of three voyages in search of the Northwest Passage, Frobisher became the first Englishman to land on which island - Canada's largest?
Frobisher returned from his voyages with over 1,500 tonnes of what he believed to be gold ore. It is now thought to have been which mineral, a calcium-rich subtype of amphibole?
Finally, Frobisher commanded the ship Triumph in which naval engagement, for which he was knighted during the operations by the Lord High Admiral Charles Howard?
questions.answer: The Battle of the Spanish Armada

bonuses.topic: Pop Music

questions.question: Your bonus, then, are on the origins of dance music genres. Juan Atkins, Jeff Mills and Robert Hood are artists principally associated with the emergence of what genre of dance music in Detroit in the 1980s?

What name is given to the genre of dance music that developed in the UK in the early 1990s out of the rave scene and reggae sound system culture, associated with acts such as A Guy Called Gerald and Goldie?
What is the stage name of the DJ and producer widely referred to as the godfather of house music? The term "house" originated as a contraction of the name of his club, the Warehouse.

bonuses.topic: Painting/Sculpture

questions.question: That picture starter was one of Titian's depictions of Danae faced by Zeus in the form of a shower of gold. For your picture bonuses, you'll see three more depictions of this scene. Five points for each artist you can identify. Firstly...
Secondly...
And finally...

bonuses.topic: on juvenilia or childhood writings by well-known authors. In each case, name the writer from the titles of the works given

questions.question: Firstly, the author of the works Love And Friendship and The History Of England written before 1793.
Secondly, High Life In Verdopolis and The Spell, set in the fictional kingdom of Angria. They were written in the 1830s under the pseudonym Lord Charles Albert Florian Wellesley.
Finally, the two sisters who wrote the Hyde Park Gate News, a fictional newspaper from 1891 onwards.

bonuses.topic: three questions on treatments for syphilis

questions.question: Discovered in 1909 by Sahachiro Hata at the laboratory of Paul Ehrlich, which arsenic-containing compound was the first effective treatment for syphilis, as well as being the first synthetic antimicrobial drug?
Next, Julius Wagner-Jauregg won the 1927 Nobel Prize in Medicine for his work treating syphilis by inducing fever. He achieved this by infecting patients with what protozoan disease?
Finally, after its isolation for clinical use by Howard Florey and Ernst Chain in the 1940s, which drug became the standard treatment for syphilis and remains so to this day?

bonuses.topic: three questions on film adaptations of a play

questions.question: "My aim was not to adapt Shakespeare to the cinema, but to adapt the cinema to Shakespeare." These words of the Soviet director Grigori Kozintsev referred to his 1964 film version of which of Shakespeare's plays using Boris Pasternak's translation?
Akira Kurosawa's 1960 film The Bad Sleep Well is a loose adaptation of Hamlet in the film noir genre. It stars which actor in the lead role, his 12th collaboration with Kurosawa?
Vishal Bhardwaj's 2014 adaptation Haider is set in 1995 against the backdrop of conflict in which disputed transnational region...? [gong]
